Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

ALLEGATION:
Youth is deaf and communicates via sign language and has been in placement since
3/25/22. Since that time, no caseworker has attempted to communicate with youth
nor has an interpreter been utilized.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on July 13, 2022. Complainant
stated Youth A was placed in her home since the end of March 2022. Complainant
stated Youth A’s siblings were placed in the home in the past so they were aware of
Youth A’s communication needs because he would occasionally visit. She stated the
agency reported Youth A only knew 20 American Sign Language (ASL) signs and
had not had any behavioral issues since January 2022. Complainant stated Youth A
knows a lot more than 20 signs. She stated Youth A has been receiving sign
language services since he was initially removed 2 years ago and attends a deaf
and hard of hearing program at school. She stated the school has encouraged her
and her husband to use sign language with Youth A as much as possible to assist
him in learning. Complainant stated Youth A uses ASL to communicate and the
agency does not involve interpreters as part of his case management. She stated
2

she requested an interpreter to communicate major changes such as termination of
his mother’s parental rights in May 2022 and when he was going to be moved from
their home in early July 2022. Complainant stated the agency told her Youth A’s
therapist, who is fluent with ASL, can communicate those changes to Youth A. She
stated she has had to fight to have the agency utilize an interpreter. She stated
when the agency foster care worker completed home visits there was never an
interpreter present other than two occasions when the therapist assisted.
Complainant stated the foster care worker would wear a mask initially, which she
understood, but without an interpreter and no way for Youth A to read lips there was
no communication between Youth A and the assigned foster care worker. She
stated there was only very minimal communication between the assigned foster care
worker and Youth A because of the communication barrier. She stated they were
told to contact the enhanced foster care team or mobile crisis team through Network
180 when Youth A escalates but that has been ineffective because EFC mobile
crisis tries to verbally deescalate Youth A and he is unable to communicate verbally.
Chief Administrator (CA) was interviewed face-to-face at the agency on July
18, 2022. CA stated she has processed vouchers for interpreter services so knows
the service has been used but was unsure how often. CA stated she will pull the
vouchers that have been processed so far to determine if interpreter services were
used during home visits and not documented in the case file. The agency utilizes
Deaf and Hard of Hearing Services for an interpreter.
Foster Care supervisor (FC Supervisor) was interviewed face-to-face at the
agency on July 18, 2022. FC Supervisor stated she was the assigned foster case
manager prior to being promoted to supervisor. She stated Youth A was initially
placed with his older sibling and an ASL interpreter was used primarily with the
sibling who demonstrated a better understanding of ASL. Youth A was not able to
engage in ASL and showed some cognitive delays. In addition, the initial foster
placement had over 15 years of ASL experience. Youth A was eventually moved to
a new foster placement due to his behavioral issues. The second foster placement
also had experience with ASL. FC supervisor stated Youth A would mimic
interpreters and not answer so the agency did not utilize interpreters as they felt it
was not beneficial. FC Supervisor stated Youth A has progressed some with his use
and understanding of ASL more recently. She stated Foster Care Worker utilized an
interpreter in May, June and July but there may have been a month or two where an
interpreter was not utilized.
FC Supervisor stated in order to secure an interpreter the agency contacts Deaf and
Hard of Hearing Services. If the request is not made at least 3 days in advance,
there is an emergency fee and there is no guarantee there will be an interpreter
available. She stated that Foster Care Worker tries to utilize the same interpreter
when visiting Youth A so it is someone familiar to him.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed face-to-face at the agency on July
18, 2022. FCW stated he has been the assigned caseworker since March 2022.
3

Youth A’s foster placement when he was initially assigned were fluent in ASL, so he
used them to assist him during home visits. FCW stated Youth A’s language skills
are closer to a 4-year-old. FCW stated Youth A would often mimic when interpreters
attempted to communicate with him. FCW stated Youth A has recently made
improvements with ASL and the agency has been utilizing interpreters since May.
FCW stated he utilized an interpreter in May to inform Youth A that his biological
mother’s parental rights had been terminated. He stated Youth A seemed to
understand more than he had in the past and his level of communication had
noticeably improved. As a result, he stated his supervisor advised him in early June
that he is to utilize an interpreter during home visits from that point forward.
FCW stated during home visits when an interpreter was not utilized, he would do the
best he could as far covering aspects of a quality visit. He stated the foster parents
were learning ASL and would assist if they were able.
Documents Reviewed:
 3/11/2020 IEP indicates Youth A was enrolled in preschool program which
uses ASL for communication and he was learning ASL. Also states his mode
of communication is ASL and gesturing.
 3/17/2021 IEP indicates Youth A is placed in a classroom that utilizes ASL
exclusively.
 MISACWIS placement record: Youth A was placed with previous foster
parents from 3/28/2022 through 7/8/2022. Youth A was at Devos from
6/28/2022-7/1/2022.
 Education section of 1/13/2022 USP states Youth A is working on language at
school.
 Invoices submitted to agency from Deaf and Hard of Hearing Services for
Youth A dated February 21, 2022, May 26, 2022, June 7, 2022, and June 14,
2022.
 MISACWIS case file: Social work contact (SWC) in which face-to-face contact
with Youth A occurred in the foster placement between 3/28/2022-7/8/2022
were reviewed. A total of 25 SWC were entered (including enhanced foster
care), 3 of those contacts noted interpreters from Deaf and Hard of Hearing
Services were present. SWC dated 5/26/2022 interpreters were present to
communicate to Youth A of the recent court action to terminate his mother’s
parental rights. SWC dated 6/7/2022 noted an interpreter was present. SWC
dated 7/8/2022 interpreters were present to communicate to Youth A that he
was being moved to a new foster placement.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(1) An agency shall develop service plans with the child, the
child's parents or legal guardian, the referring agency, and
the other parties involved in providing needed services, or
medical care, unless the agency documents why any of the
entities have not been involved.
4

ANALYSIS: Based on interviews conducted and review of Youth A’s
MISACWIS case file, the agency did not always utilize American
Sign Language interpreters when conducting face-to-face
meetings with Youth A in the foster placement. Individualized
Education Plans were reviewed for the past 2 years, and those
documents indicate Youth A’s sole method of communication
while at school is ASL.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
In order for a quality visit to occur between the foster care
caseworker and the youth, they need to be able to communicate
with the use of interpreter services not relying on the placement
provider to allow the youth to provide feedback in a safe setting.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan no change be
made to the license of this child placing agency.
